title: Easy Steps to Find the Reference Angle in Degrees & Radians

steps.title: The reference angle is made by the x-axis and terminal side of an angle.
steps.content: The reference angle is made by the x-axis and terminal side of an angle. Every angle has an initial side, which is the ray that falls on the x-axis, and a terminal side, which is the angleâ€™s other ray. [2] X Research source Note : Reference angles are always positive and less than or equal to 90Â°. A ray is a straight line with 1 endpoint.

steps.title: Find the reference angle based on the quadrant the given angle is in.

steps.title: The trig function is the same for the given angle and reference angle.
steps.content: The trig function is the same for the given angle and reference angle. When finding the sine, cosine, tangent, or other trigonometric function of an angle, the value is the same for the given angle and the reference angle. This comes in handy when the given angle is an uncommon angle but the reference angle is an angle you already know the answer to, like 30Â° or 45Â°. [11] X Research source For instance, you might be asked to find the value of sine 210Â°. You likely donâ€™t know the answer off the top of your head, but you can easily determine that the reference angle of 210Â° is 30Â°. Sine 30Â° is Â½, so sine 210Â° is -Â½. Note : The sine might be different for the given and reference angle. Each trig function is positive or negative, depending on the quadrant the angle is in: Quadrant 1 : All functions are positive. Quadrant 2 : Only sine is positive. Quadrant 3 : Only tangent is positive. Quadrant 4 : Only cosine is positive.
